SectionBody.Text: For purposes of implementing s. 14, Art. V of the State Constitution, the elements of the state courts system to be provided from state revenues appropriated by general law are as follows:

Subsection.Text: Judges appointed or elected pursuant to chapters 25, 26, 34, and 35.
Reasonable court reporting and transcription services necessary to meet constitutional requirements.
Construction or lease of facilities, maintenance, utilities, and security for the district courts of appeal and the Supreme Court.
Court foreign language and sign-language interpreters and translators essential to comply with constitutional requirements.
Expert witnesses who are appointed by the court pursuant to an express grant of statutory authority.
Judicial assistants, law clerks, and resource materials.
General magistrates, special magistrates, and hearing officers.

Paragraph.Text: Initial review and evaluation of cases, including assignment of cases to court divisions or dockets.
Service referral, coordination, monitoring, and tracking for treatment-based drug court programs under s. 397.334.

Subsection.Text: Case management may not include costs associated with the application of therapeutic jurisprudence principles by the courts. Case management also may not include case intake and records management conducted by the clerk of court.

Mediation and arbitration, limited to trial court referral of a pending judicial case to a mediator or a court-related mediation program, or to an arbitrator or a court-related arbitration program, for the limited purpose of encouraging and assisting the litigants in partially or completely settling the case prior to adjudication on the merits by the court. This does not include citizen dispute settlement centers under s. 44.201 and community arbitration programs under s. 985.16.
Basic legal materials reasonably accessible to the public other than a public law library. These materials may be provided in a courthouse facility or any library facility.
Offices of the appellate clerks and marshals and appellate law libraries.
